awd_titl_txt: RAPID: COVID-19 and Perceptions of Electoral Integrity
awd_abstract_narration:
Concerns regarding election fraud and election manipulation associated with the substantial expansion of voting by mail in the 2020 elections due to COVID-19 may threaten citizens’ trust in American election outcomes and the electoral system. This study provides insights into public beliefs about voter fraud related to mail-in voting and the effectiveness of new information provided through social media and media outlets. The study also assesses how people’s beliefs and experiences with COVID-19 are related to their perceptions of electoral integrity.

The study collects behavioral and survey data from Americans in a multi-wave nationally representative survey. The panel survey design compares the accuracy of citizens’ factual beliefs about the prevalence of voter fraud between late summer 2020 and two survey waves conducted immediately following the election in November 2020 and just prior to the presidential inauguration in January 2021. The second wave includes an experiment evaluating the effectiveness of corrective information from the media. The study assesses the information people encounter online about the election by analyzing behavioral data from respondents using human-coded and machine learning approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research has shown that misperceptions about the prevalence of voter fraud in U.S. elections are common, difficult to correct, and associated with distrust of election results. It is therefore critical to measure the information people receive about voter fraud, the beliefs they express on the topic, and the effectiveness of fact-checking in increasing the accuracy of those beliefs.

Using a panel survey design, we track changes in the accuracy of people’s factual beliefs about the prevalence of voter fraud in late summer 2020, following the election in December 2020, and just prior to the presidential inauguration in January 2021. Our results provide new evidence of the extent of the increase in fraud perceptions during this period among supporters of the incumbent president. On average, people who approved of President Trump’s job performance went from indicating that six types of voter fraud would be committed thousands of times each in the 2020 election to saying afterward that each type of fraud had been committed tens of thousands of times during the election. 

We also conducted a randomized experiment in which some participants were asked to read an actual fact-check article that debunks five false claims about voter and election fraud that were prevalent at the time the study was fielded. The results show that exposure to fact-checking information debunking popular myths about the prevalence of voter fraud increases belief in the accuracy of true claims, reduces belief in false claims, and increases people’s ability to discern between them (i.e., the difference in perceived accuracy). The effects on discernment were greatest among Republicans and people who approved of Trump’s performance in office or felt warmly toward him and for people who performed worst at distinguishing true from false claims about the election result in the prior survey wave. 

Finally, we provide the first evidence of exposure to voter fraud claims using online behavior data. Using text analysis and supervised learning techniques, we show that exposure to voter fraud claims substantially increased after the election before declining after the January 6, 2021 attack on the US Capitol. Most information people saw about the topic came from reliable news sources, though we do observe an increase in exposure to unreliable sources in the post-election period.

These results provide new insights into the factors affecting public confidence in the election system, how it changes when under attack, and how effective fact-checking is as a response to false information. In future work, we will publish these results in scientific journals and offer practical recommendations for policymakers, officials, and journalists for combating misperceptions and bolstering confidence in elections.
